author: By Shaila Dewan and Julie Bosman
title: O.J. Simpson Trial Served as a Landmark Moment for Domestic Violence Awareness
description: His acquittal in the infamous trial involving Nicole Brown Simpson’s death prompted powerful backlash that helped change the perception around domestic violence.
content: In December 1994, investigators from the Los Angeles County prosecutor’s office drilled open a safe deposit box that had belonged to Nicole Brown Simpson. In it, they found Polaroids of her with a battered face and letters from O.J. Simpson apologizing for abusing her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: A Soccer Bridesmaid Readies the Crown, and Germany (Mostly) Likes the Look
description: Bayer Leverkusen can win its first Bundesliga title this weekend. For its rivals, the real joy comes in seeing Bayern Munich lose it.
content: Executives at Bayer Leverkusen, the longstanding but habitually middleweight German soccer team, have been fielding the messages since at least February. Some were delivered in person, a quiet blessing after yet another victory. Others came via WhatsApp, unsolicited and unexpected notes from peers and acquaintances and, to their occasional surprise, foes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Ohtani’s Dizzying 3 Weeks End in Exoneration by Authorities
description: At times, baseball’s biggest star seemed in danger of being tainted by a gambling scandal, before his longtime interpreter was charged with fraud.
content: In the clubhouse after the Los Angeles Dodgers won their season opener in Seoul last month, Shohei Ohtani’s longtime interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, made a stunning admission to the team: He was a gambling addict, and Ohtani had paid his debts to a bookmaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Evans and Tatsiana Chypsanava
title: New Zealanders Are Crazy for This Fruit. It’s Not the Kiwi.
description: Like the kiwi fruit, the feijoa, or pineapple guava, is not native to the island nation, but it has become something of a national obsession.
content: Autumn in New Zealand heralds the arrival of a green, egg-size fruit that falls off trees in such abundance that it is often given to neighbors and colleagues by the bucket or even the wheelbarrow load. Only in cases of extreme desperation do people buy any.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Desmond
title: You Don’t Have to Take Every Tax Deduction, and You Shouldn’t
description: Many exemptions are very hard, perhaps impossibly hard, to defend on either practical or moral grounds.
content: Alejandro Narváez is OK taking less. He hires only contractors who pay their workers a living wage, even if that means a larger bill. A Seattle-based dentist, he’s promoted cost-effective practices to expand dental care to the underserved, even if those practices cut into his bottom line. And when it comes to paying taxes, he forgoes many deductions afforded him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Biotech Exec Gets 7 Years in Prison for False Claims About Rapid Covid-19 Test
description: Prosecutors said Keith Berman falsely claimed he had invented a blood test that could detect Covid-19 in 15 seconds. His lawyer said he had put “genuine effort” into developing such a test.
content: The former chief executive of a biotechnology company who, during the early days of the pandemic, falsely claimed that he had invented a blood test that could detect Covid-19 in 15 seconds was sentenced on Friday to seven years in prison for securities fraud, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John White, Larissa Anderson, Melissa Kirsch, Manohla Dargis and Carole Sabouraud
title: ‘Civil War’ Is Designed to Disturb You
description: Here’s why you should watch it anyway.
content: On Friday, “Civil War” was released in theaters across the United States and Britain. Written and directed by Alex Garland, the film imagines a future in which America is at war with itself and four journalists must risk their lives to travel to the White House and interview the president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Frank Olson, Executive Who Linked O.J. Simpson With Hertz, Dies at 91
description: He negotiated Mr. Simpson’s star turn in commercials, tapping into his football fame, and formed a social bond with him — until there were murder charges. They died on the same day.
content: Frank A. Olson, who as a top executive of Hertz cast the running back O.J. Simpson as the star of the company’s commercials — a corporate marriage that shined up both parties and that lasted two decades, until Mr. Simpson was charged in a double homicide in 1994 — died at his home in Palm Beach, Fla., on Wednesday, the same day Mr. Simpson died. Mr. Olson was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrienne Raphel
title: How Gen Z Made the Crossword Their Own
description: A younger generation of constructors is using an old form to reflect their identities, language and world.
content: 30-Across: “___ and dry food (categories I will now be using to describe human food. Oh, so suddenly it’s weird?)”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: 3 Facts That Help Explain a Confusing Economic Moment
description: The path to a “soft landing” doesn’t seem as smooth as it did four months ago. But the expectations of a year ago have been surpassed.
content: The economic news of the past two weeks has been enough to leave even seasoned observers feeling whipsawed. The unemployment rate fell. Inflation rose. The stock market plunged, then rebounded, then dropped again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: You Ask, We Answer: How The Times/Siena Poll Is Conducted
description: The New York Times/Siena College Poll has earned a reputation for accuracy and transparency. But as with any poll, there are limits to just how much you can derive.
content: Polls can give us important insight into how people’s views on the issues, the state of the country and the candidates may affect how they vote. Polls have helped us understand how motivating issues like abortion and immigration are for Americans, how the war in Gaza is perceived by Democrats and Republicans, and how many voters believe misinformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: How a Reality TV Show Turned the U.F.C. From Pariah to Juggernaut
description: The Ultimate Fighting Championship, whose 300th numbered pay-per-view fight card is this weekend, was once effectively banned on television because of its violence.
content: Twenty years ago, the Ultimate Fighting Championship was on life support. Broadcasters scoffed at the idea of televising half-naked men pummeling each other inside a caged octagon, engaged in a sport where broken bones and dislodged teeth were common. Venues closed their doors and advertisers their wallets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin
title: Indigenous Artists Are the Heart of the Venice Biennale
description: Here are highlights of the range of work produced by Native artists in the pavilions and a central exhibition that proudly calls itself “Foreigners Everywhere.”
content: Before visitors step into any gallery at the 2024 Venice Biennale, which opens April 20, Indigenous artists will have made their presence known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Most N.Y.C. Drivers Who Honk Are Breaking the Law. Can They Be Stopped?
description: The city’s noise code has limited the use of vehicle horns for almost a century. Enforcing the law is another matter.
content: Hardly a second had passed since the light turned green, but there was already a symphony of honks and beeps and toots urging traffic forward on Columbus Avenue. About a minute later, a deep, foghorn-like honk rumbled from a dump truck as it turned onto 89th Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emi Nietfeld and Kristina Samulewski
title: Harvard Is Bringing Back Standardized Tests. Other Schools Should, Too.
description: Emi Nietfeld didn’t have access to lacrosse or advanced placement classes, but she did have standardized tests.
content: Harvard University is among the latest institutions to announce it is reversing its test-optional policy and requiring students to submit test scores in their applications. For the writer Emi Nietfeld, it’s a positive sign. Growing up homeless and in the foster care system, she didn’t have a lot of control over her education or resources that would bolster her college applications. But one thing she did have control over was studying for standardized tests. In this audio essay, Nietfeld explains how Scantron sheets helped her unlock a better life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 13, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 13, 2024.
content: A theater review on Friday about the musical version of “The Outsiders” in one instance misidentified the folk duo that wrote the score for “The Outsiders.” It is Jamestown Revival, not Johnstown Revival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The Gen Z Crossword Era
description: Solving a crossword puzzle today feels more like a spirited conversation with modern culture.
content: My 20-year-old niece, Emma, texted the other day to tell me she’s addicted to The Times’s game Connections; she and her friends play every day, along with the Mini and Strands. “The people who make the games need to make more fun games,” she declared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: When O.J. Simpson ‘Confessed’ to Murder
description: Years after Mr. Simpson was acquitted, he wrote a book and gave a shocking interview. The whole endeavor cost the publisher, Judith Regan, her job.
content: In 1995, O.J. Simpson pleaded not guilty to murdering his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald Goldman. He was acquitted by a jury. But a little more than a decade later, he more or less confessed to the crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Inside Donald Trump’s Embrace of the Jan. 6 Rioters
description: The former president initially disavowed the attack on the Capitol, but he is now making it a centerpiece of his general election campaign.
content: Two days before former President Donald J. Trump was booked at an Atlanta jail on his fourth indictment, he held an event at his golf club in New Jersey for another group of people facing criminal charges: rioters accused of storming the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: What Are the Stakes of ‘Civil War,’ Really?
description: Alex Garland’s new film is most interested in the experience of living through an armed conflict.
content: Ahead of the release of “Civil War,” the new alt-history action-drama from the director Alex Garland, A24, the studio that produced the film, released a map of the United States showing the lines of the conflict. There was the “New People’s Army” of the Pacific Northwest, the Mountain West and some of the Great Plains. There were the “Western Forces” of Texas and California. And there was the “Florida Alliance,” encompassing most of the Southeast. What remained was labeled “the Loyalist States.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Bondi Junction, Site of Stabbing Attack, Is a Popular and Busy Hub
description: As well as a major mall, the area contains cafes and yoga studios. It’s a gateway from central Sydney, Australia, to eastern suburbs and several popular beaches.
content: Tourists wandering the sprawling mall for gifts. Beachgoers picking up sunscreen before heading to the water. Friends meeting for coffee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Sylvester
title: Some Words Feel Truer in Spanish
description: To me, a maleta meant family had arrived from Peru, carrying flavors, textures and memories of my birthplace.
content: My earliest relationship with language was defined by rules. As an immigrant who came to this country from Peru at age 4, I spent half of my days in kindergarten occupied with learning the rules of the English language. There was the tricky inconsistency of pronunciation to navigate and, once I learned to speak it, the challenge of translating what I’d learned into reading skills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Judge Rejects Hunter Biden Claim of Selective Prosecution in Gun Case
description: Judge Maryellen Noreika declined to dismiss the charges against the president’s son, saying Mr. Biden’s lawyer failed to show prosecutors had been motivated by animus.
content: The federal judge presiding over Hunter Biden’s gun case in Delaware on Friday rejected Mr. Biden’s claim that he was being subjected to selective prosecution, saying it was “nonsensical” that the Biden Justice Department would target the president’s son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Like Some Smiles and Winks
description: Even in her first Times puzzle, Jess Rucks knows what everyone needs on a Saturday: a ray of sunshine.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — If you’re hoping for one of those themeless solves that are a breath of fresh air, full of crowd-pleasing trivia and accessible humor, then you’ve come to the right place. This is a polished crossword by a seasoned constructor who’s debuting at The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Pittsburgh Reopens Bridge After 26 Barges Break Loose on Ohio River
description: The barges, some carrying coal, damaged a marina. One barge, which likely sank, remained missing on Saturday, an official said.
content: The authorities in Pittsburgh reopened a bridge that had been closed as a precaution after 26 barges broke loose on the Ohio River late on Friday, drifting miles downstream and damaging a marina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Isabella Kwai
title: Witnesses to Sydney Mall Stabbing Describe Harrowing Scenes
description: People who were at the scene told of chaos, screaming, wounded victims and a resolute attacker. Many struggled to process the shock hours afterward.
content: Witnesses to the stabbings at a mall in a Sydney, Australia, on Saturday described a scene of terror as shoppers fled from the knife-wielding man or huddled in stores as panic spread through the shopping center.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Coffee Means Connection, Even in War
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 13, 2024.
content: “Despite the war, people were still thinking about coffee. They could leave their homes, their habits. But they could not live without coffee.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Johnson Floats Voting on Senate Ukraine Bill, With Conservative Policies as Sweeteners
description: The Republican speaker has weighed bringing up a $95 billion Senate-passed bill to aid Ukraine and Israel in tandem with a separate package geared toward mollifying G.O.P. critics.
content: Shortly after congressional leaders met with Japan’s prime minister in Speaker Johnson’s ceremonial office in the Capitol on Thursday morning, the conversation turned to Ukraine aid.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Reduce Student Absenteeism
description: Readers discuss the reasons for the spike since the pandemic and how to lure students back.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Too Soon?
description: A look back at O.J. Simpson’s attempt to reboot his media career, and more stories.
content: A look back at O.J. Simpson’s attempt to reboot his media career, plus more stories about knowing the right moment for something to happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Doug Mills
title: The Landline’s Not Dead (at Least at the Masters)
description: Augusta National Golf Club has long forbidden cellphones for almost anyone at its hallowed tournament, but patrons delight in making free calls the old-school way.
content: They call to check in with their bosses or spouses. They call to brag. They call to offer up weather reports, food reviews, golf commentaries, celebrity sightings, souvenir spending confessions, legal advice and trips down memory lane. This year, they called to talk about the solar eclipse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Hawthorne
title: Philip Johnson’s Brick House and Its Hidden Boudoir, Exposed
description: The Glass House in Connecticut has its 75th anniversary, followed by the reopening of its long-mute twin, “warmer and toastier and sexier.”
content: Diptych, dyad, dialectic: The relationship between the first pair of buildings Philip Johnson designed for his estate in New Canaan, Conn., has taxed the metaphorical imaginations of critics and architectural historians since the structures were completed, just months apart, in 1949.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Sarah Kessler and Bernhard Warner
title: Golf’s Big Deal Veers Off Course
description: The Masters tournament should be all about sport, but the unresolved fight between the PGA Tour and LIV Golf looms over the competition.
content: The Masters is a tournament steeped in tradition and hosts one of sports’ most storied gatherings: the champions dinner, when former winners meet at Augusta National Golf Club, and the previous year’s winner sets the menu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: N.Y.P.D. Defends Contentious Arrests of ‘Violence Interrupters’
description: The arrests, which led one of the men to be hospitalized, heightened tensions between officers and outreach workers trained to intervene in street conflicts.
content: The New York Police Department continued on Friday to defend its arrests of two conflict mediators in Brooklyn in February, releasing body-camera and surveillance videos of the episode that police officials said showed one of the workers striking an officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Iran Seizes Commercial Ship Linked to Israel
description: Directly and through proxy groups like the Houthis in Yemen, Iran has been disrupting commercial shipping in the Persian Gulf for years.
content: Iranian forces seized a container ship with links to Israel in the Persian Gulf on Saturday, as leaders in the Middle East and beyond watched for a retaliatory strike by Iran against Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden Shrinks Trump’s Edge in Latest Times/Siena Poll
description: The president’s popularity has ticked up slightly, though voters still view Donald J. Trump more favorably and have dour views of the economy.
content: President Biden has nearly erased Donald J. Trump’s early polling advantage, amid signs that the Democratic base has begun to coalesce behind the president despite lingering doubts about the direction of the country, the economy and his age, according to a new survey by The New York Times and Siena College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Vogt
title: How America Is Picking Up the Pieces of a Broken Global Order
description: In “New Cold Wars,” David E. Sanger tracks the shifts in U.S. foreign policy as competition among the great powers re-emerges in the 21st century.
content: In recent years, the human toll of disease and war has been heartbreaking. But geopolitical upheaval and the return of great-power competition have also brought a fascinating revival of first-order questions: How does deterrence work? Does economic interdependence make countries less likely to fight? Does rising prosperity force authoritarian regimes to reform?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Lobrano
title: It’s Not Just a Wedding Cake, It’s ‘Edible Haute Couture’
description: Bastien Blanc-Tailleur, a luxury cake designer based in Paris, creates opulent confections for high-profile clients, including European royalty and American socialites.
content: Sebastien Blanc-Tailleur, a Parisian pâtissier, has always had a passion for confections. “I’ve been obsessed by pastry since I was a little boy,” he said. Since opening his eponymous business in 2015, Mr. Blanc-Tailleur has discretely become one of the most prestigious creators of wedding and special-occasion cakes in France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: Who Cares if Supreme Court Justices Get Along?
description: What really matters is what the court does or doesn’t do.
content: The Supreme Court is hurting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Police Who Killed Bronx Man Won’t Face Punishment
description: The officers, Brendan Thompson and Herbert Davis, were previously cleared of criminal wrongdoing in the fatal 2019 shooting of Kawaski Trawick.
content: Two New York City police officers involved in the fatal shooting of a 32-year-old Bronx man in his kitchen in 2019 acted within the law and will not be punished, the city’s police commissioner said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: As ‘Sex and the City’ Ages, Some Find the Cosmo Glass Half-Empty
description: As the show became more widely available on Netflix, younger viewers have watched it with a critical eye. But its longtime millennial and Gen X fans can’t quit.
content: Most weeks, hundreds of people board a “Sex and the City” themed bus in Manhattan that takes them to the show’s most recognizable sites: Carrie Bradshaw’s apartment, her favorite brunch spot, a sex shop in the West Village. The tour usually ends with — what else? — a Cosmopolitan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Savings Plan
description: John Rippe and Jeff Chen collaborate on a puzzle with a big heart.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Steinhauer
title: Representing the U.S. and Critiquing It in a Psychedelic Rainbow
description: Jeffrey Gibson’s history-making turn at the Venice Biennale brings the gay and Native American artist center stage with works of struggle and freedom.
content: People in Venice might hear the jingle dress dancers before they see them. On April 18, some 26 intertribal Native American dancers and singers from Oklahoma and Colorado will make their way through the winding streets and canals of the Italian city. Wearing brightly colored shawls, beaded yokes and dresses decorated with the metal cones that give the dance its distinctive cshh cshh rattling sound, they’ll make their way to the Giardini, one of the primary sites of the Venice Biennale. There, they’ll climb atop and surround a large red sculpture composed of pedestals of different heights and perform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Jonathan Swan
title: Protests, Traffic, Crowds: Court Braces for a Trump Trial Like No Other
description: Strict security measures — and plenty of headaches — are expected as the first criminal trial of a former U.S. president gets underway in Manhattan.
content: Manhattan’s Criminal Courts Building, at 100 Centre Street, is short on charm: circled in scaffolding, lit like an aging cafeteria and, in recent months, neighbor to a colossal pile of rubble, the remains of the Manhattan Detention Complex, which is being demolished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Don Wright, Editorial Cartoonist With a Skewer for a Pen, Dies at 90
description: He won two Pulitzers for Florida newspapers, commenting wryly on war, segregation, church scandals and more while reaching readers nationwide through syndication.
content: Don Wright, a two-time Pulitzer Prize-winning editorial cartoonist whose pointed work punctured duplicity and pomposity and resonated with common-sense readers, died on March 24 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Four South Dakota Tribes Bar Gov. Kristi Noem, Trump V.P. Contender, From Lands
description: The tribes barred the Republican governor from their reservations after she told lawmakers that Mexican drug cartels had a foothold there and were committing murders.
content: Four of South Dakota’s federally recognized Native American tribes have barred the state’s governor, Kristi Noem — a Republican whose name has been floated as a potential running mate for former President Donald J. Trump — from their reservations. The latest blocked Ms. Noem on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Bowen Yang Thinks This Artist Nails What It’s Like Living in New York
description: The “S.N.L.” comedian talked about his Audible series “Hot White Heist” and solitude — a state of being he senses in Edward Hopper’s paintings.
content: Bowen Yang had just played an overcompensating straight guy opposite Sydney Sweeney on “Saturday Night Live.” But in a video call from his Brooklyn apartment, he was all about “Hot White Heist,” his queer action-comedy audio series on Audible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Christopher F. Schuetze and Julia Jacobs
title: Tensions Flare in West Bank After Israeli Teenager Is Found Dead
description: The killing, which Israel called a “terrorist attack,” prompted rioting by Israeli settlers that killed one Palestinian and raised fears of a broader escalation.
content: The disappearance and death of an Israeli teenager, whose body was found on Saturday in the West Bank, spurred deadly rioting by Israeli settlers in Palestinian villages, ratcheting up tensions even further in the occupied territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margalit Fox
title: Faith Ringgold Dies at 93; Wove Black Life Into Quilts and Children’s Books
description: A champion of Black artists, she explored themes of race, gender, class, family and community through a vast array of media and later the written word.
content: Faith Ringgold, a multimedia artist whose pictorial quilts depicting the African American experience gave rise to a second distinguished career as a writer and illustrator of children’s books, died on Saturday at her home in Englewood, N.J. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Burt
title: What if K-Pop Stars Are Actually Just Like Us?
description: In the debut novel “The Band,” a burned-out pop idol meets a disillusioned professor, raising the question: What if the dangers of fame resemble white-collar ennui?
content: K-pop idols, the international megastars of Korean music, inhabit a strange, fascinating place in the ecosystems of modern culture. In some ways, they’re just like the stars of generations past, like the Beatles or the Backstreet Boys: worshiped for their youth; admired as sex objects; lauded for voices and songs that millions can’t forget; raised up, and sometimes crushed, by a fickle public and a corporate machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Emmett Lindner
title: The Sydney Mall Stabbing Rampage: What We Know
description: The attack happened in a busy center for tourists and beachgoers in the eastern suburbs, an affluent area of Sydney.
content: A stabbing attack on Saturday afternoon at a crowded mall in Sydney, Australia, left six people dead and at least 11 others injured, including a 9-month-old girl. The rampage was the deadliest act of mass violence in the country since 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder, Kevin Draper and Doug Mills
title: $17,000 to Watch the Masters? How Sports Entice Deep-Pocketed Fans.
description: Teams, leagues and event organizers are pursuing enthusiasts with the promise of luxury and exclusivity, in hopes of bigger profits and lasting loyalty.
content: The oysters and shrimp cocktail emerge by midmorning, nestled neatly on ice. The pastries look as if they were overnighted from Paris, even as the signature breakfast sandwich — a biscuit with fried chicken, pimento cheese and hot honey — showcases Southern cuisine. An Augusta National Golf Club green jacket hangs on the wall, and 81 televisions show the theatrics and athletic brilliance unfolding on the emerald grounds that host the Masters Tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: The Age of the Open Letter Should End
description: The open letter, as a genre, is far too limited. We speak with conviction, and then what?
content: Once upon a time, it is often suggested, people with starkly different viewpoints were able to convene and compromise and find hallowed common ground. This all happened in a “better time,” one invoked in fraught political discussions in which the discourse is not happening in exactly the way the invoker prefers. If only we could get back to that place, we could solve all our problems. We could overcome our differences. We could create lasting change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Lawmaker Presses Luxury Designer After Reports of Exploiting Indigenous Workers
description: A freshman congressman is demanding answers from the fashion house Loro Piana, which sources wool from his native Peru and faces accusations of exploiting workers there.
content: A $9,000 designer sweater made out of the ultrarare fur of a South American animal called a vicuña is not exactly a typical area of focus for a member of the U.S. Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why Can’t Biden Triangulate Like Trump?
description: There’s a difference between being aware of your base and being its prisoner.
content: For anyone with sincere and absolute convictions on abortion, pro-life or pro-choice, Donald Trump’s attempts to reposition himself this week should be somewhere between depressing and infuriating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: In the Nigeria Pavilion, Criticism Meets Optimism
description: The group show “Nigeria Imaginary” will be one of the most ambitious African presentations ever at the Venice Biennale.
content: People in Lagos, Nigeria’s largest city, are hardly shy. The stereotype runs toward boisterousness, worn as a point of pride. But when the artist and poet Precious Okoyomon recorded interviews with some 60 city residents in January for an art project, the unusual questions — like “Who was responsible for the suffering of your mother?” — proved disarming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: Some Used to Dread Readings. Now They Sell Out.
description: These days, literary events in New York City can require tickets and be just as hard to get into as the hottest restaurant.
content: When the writer and professor Amitava Kumar invited the book scout Erin Edmison to his reading at McNally Jackson Books’ Seaport location in February, Ms. Edmison penciled it into her calendar and “didn’t think twice about it,” she said, “because I am old, and that’s the way things used to work.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung
title: In Ukraine’s West, Draft Dodgers Run, and Swim, to Avoid the War
description: With Russia seizing the initiative on the battlefield in recent months, Ukraine’s ability to defend itself hinges on replenishing its arsenal of weaponry and mobilizing troops.
content: The roiling water can be treacherous, the banks are steep and slick with mud, and the riverbed is covered in jagged, hidden boulders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: State Dept. Is Sending Its Top Diplomat for East Asia to China
description: The announcement comes days after President Biden met jointly with the leaders of Japan and the Philippines to discuss Chinese aggression in the Indo-Pacific region.
content: The top U.S. diplomat for East Asia will travel to China on Sunday, the State Department announced, just days after President Biden met with the leaders of Japan and the Philippines in Washington as part of a broad diplomatic outreach in the region to counter China’s aggression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Safak Timur
title: Cable Car Drops Passengers Onto Mountain in Turkey, Killing One
description: Scores of people were stranded, some overnight, after an accident on a rocky hillside above the city of Antalya.
content: A cable car ferrying passengers in a mountainous area of southern Turkey broke apart after colliding with part of the metal structure supporting it on Friday, sending its eight terrified occupants plummeting to the rocky hillside below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Military Aid to Israel Cannot Be Unconditional
description: Israel’s leader has turned his back on America’s entreaties.
content: The suffering of civilians in Gaza — tens of thousands dead, many of them children; hundreds of thousands homeless, many at risk of starvation — has become more than a growing number of Americans can abide. And yet Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his ultranationalist allies in government have defied American calls for more restraint and humanitarian help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Do Ground-Floor Co-op Apartments Really Have to Carpet Their Floors?
description: Carpeting rules are common. But housing laws protect residents with disabilities, to a point.
content: Q: My mother has bad allergies and had to remove all of the carpets from her home many years ago. Now she’s looking to downsize, and we found a ground-floor apartment in a co-op in Nassau County. But the house rules require wall-to-wall carpeting, with padding, in every room except bathrooms and kitchens — even in ground-floor units, where no one lives below you. We put a deposit on the apartment, which has beautiful hardwood floors that had never been carpeted, and we know of at least two other apartments that also don’t have carpet. There’s a $500 monthly fine for noncompliance. We’re afraid that if we raise the issue, they will deny us the apartment. What should we do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Weber
title: Fritz Peterson, Yankee Pitcher in an Unusual ‘Trade,’ Dies at 82
description: He was a leading light on an undistinguished team. But he became known less for his achievement on the field than for exchanging wives with a teammate.
content: Fritz Peterson, who was a stalwart pitcher for the ineffectual Yankees of the late 1960s and early ’70s, but whose lingering renown derived more from one of baseball’s most notorious “trades” — his exchange of wives with a teammate — has died. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Banana Bread, Always and Forever
description: As long as we have bananas that go brown, we will have Julia Moskin’s perfect banana bread.
content: My relationship with bananas can best be described by paraphrasing Katy Perry’s 2008 song: We’re hot then we’re cold, we’re yes then we’re no, we’re in then we’re out, we’re up then we’re down. I’ll bring home a Donkey Kong-size haul of them on a Sunday, craving their starchy sweetness. On Monday and Tuesday I’ll proudly peel some for my breakfasts and lunches. But by Friday, I’ll have a pile of forgotten soft crescents streaked with black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Protesters in Niger Call for U.S. Military Exit as Russian Force Arrives
description: Trainers and equipment from Russia landed in the West African nation this week, putting the continued presence of 1,000 U.S. military personnel there in doubt.
content: Thousands of protesters gathered in the capital of Niger on Saturday called for the withdrawal of U.S. armed forces personnel stationed in the West African nation, only days after Russia delivered its own set of military equipment and instructors to the country’s military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle, Melissa Guerrero, Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet and Rebecca Smeyne
title: Lewis Hamilton, Swizz Beatz and Nine Inch Nails Toast Influential Artists
description: This week, the Brooklyn Museum honored the work of Titus Kaphar at their Artists Ball, and GQ hosted an awards show in the Financial District.
content: On Tuesday night, as joggers wove down Eastern Parkway toward Prospect Park, art world fixtures stepped out of black cars and filed past blossoming trees into the Brooklyn Museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Why a Liberal Premier Wants to Pause a Carbon Tax Increase
description: Andrew Furey, Canada’s only Liberal premier, recently asked the Liberal federal government to suspend the scheduled increases.
content: When Canadians debate the place of the country’s oil industry in a carbon-constrained future, the conversation usually focuses on Alberta and, to a lesser extent, Saskatchewan. Often overlooked is Newfoundland and Labrador, where offshore drilling accounts for 5 percent of all of Canada’s oil production and just under a quarter of its light oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Death of 14-year-old Ignites More Violence in West Bank
description: Dozens of Israelis and Palestinians were wounded during clashes at several locations across the West Bank on Saturday after a missing teenage boy was found dead.
content: An Israeli teenager whose disappearance had led to riots by Israeli settlers in the West Bank was found dead on Saturday, the Israeli authorities said, threatening to further inflame tensions in the Israeli-occupied territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner and Nathalia Angarita
title: In a Global Cycling Capital, Riders Fear Becoming Crime Victims
description: In Bogotá, a city with more than 1.1 million bicycles and a strong riding culture, a number of high-profile crimes have rattled cyclists.
content: Bicycles are an essential part of the Colombian identity — ubiquitous, cheaper and, in some urban communities, often a faster way to get around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: For Many Western Allies, Sending Weapons to Israel Gets Dicey
description: As civilian casualties in Gaza spiral, some nations are suspending sales amid accusations of abetting genocide and war crimes.
content: For months, Western governments have provided military support for Israel while fending off accusations that their weapons were being used to commit war crimes in Gaza. But as a global outcry over the growing death toll in Gaza mounts, maintaining that balance is becoming increasingly difficult, as was clear on a single day this past week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: How a Raunchy Lounge Singer Spends His Sundays
description: Dani Lubnitzki, who is better known as Dani Luv, puts his own spin on Sinatra during the week, but on Sundays he shops for his grandchildren and has a jam session with friends.
content: For more than two decades, Dani Lubnitzki was the resident lounge singer and pianist at Sammy’s Roumanian Steakhouse on the Lower East Side, where bottles of vodka were served lodged in blocks of ice and the entertainment was as schmaltzy as the chopped liver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Benjamin Weiser
title: Stacks of Cash at Menendez Home Were Not From His Bank, Prosecutors Say
description: The senator has said that money found in his house was from his own savings account. But prosecutors said that at least some of it came from “another person.”
content: When Senator Robert Menendez was charged last year with corruption after investigators found $486,000 in cash stashed around his house in New Jersey, he offered a simple, “old-fashioned” explanation: It had been his custom to withdraw cash from a personal savings account to keep at home, a habit he learned from his Cuban immigrant parents.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Books About Other People’s Money
description: A tax manifesto by Edmund Wilson and a money-themed story collection.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edan Lepucki
title: A Modern California Dream, Still Haunted by Hippie Darkness
description: Cult leaders, curdled 1960s idealism and outsider art collide in Max Ludington’s prismatic novel, “Thorn Tree.”
content: For every idyllic image of the 1960s there exists its dark inverse, a symbol of menacing chaos. Give me your flower crowns at Woodstock, your free love in Haight-Ashbury, and I’ll hand you the murdering Manson family, or the 5-year-old in Joan Didion’s “Slouching Toward Bethlehem,” high on the LSD her mother gave her. This slippage of the utopian into the dystopian lies at the heart of “Thorn Tree,” Max Ludington’s ominous second novel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Mall Attack Was Australia’s Worst Mass Violence in Years
description: Saturday’s stabbing attack in Sydney horrified a country not used to such acts.
content: The stabbing attack in a Sydney shopping center that left at least six people dead on Saturday was Australia’s worst act of mass violence since 2017, when a driver killed six people by deliberately plowing his car into pedestrians in Melbourne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Review: In ‘Symphony of Rats’ Revival, a Darkness Goes Underexplored
description: The Wooster Group’s staging of Richard Foreman’s play operates like a delightful love letter from one giant of experimental theater to another.
content: A president losing grip with reality. Warnings of environmental disaster and apocalypse. An early reference to the Covid vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Sameer Yasir
title: China Had a ‘Special Place’ in Modi’s Heart. Now It’s a Thorn in His Side.
description: As Narendra Modi seeks a third term as prime minister, India’s rupture with China looms over a pillar of his campaign: making his country a major power.
content: Narendra Modi once looked up to China. As a business-friendly Indian state leader, he traveled there repeatedly to attract investment and see how his country could learn from its neighbor’s economic transformation. China, he said, has a “special place in my heart.” Chinese officials cheered on his march to national power as that of “a political star.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kesslen, Erica Dischino, Erin Schaff and Dustin Miller
title: Finding Comfort in a Haircut
description: A good cut is hard to find no matter where you live. But some hairstylists know it holds more weight for their transgender clients.
content: Xavier Cruz and JP Gomez, a married gay couple, knew discrimination against the L.G.B.T.Q. community had become widespread. But as owners of Barba Grooming Boutique, a salon in Manhattan, they thought their industry was largely immune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: A.I. Made These Movies Sharper. Critics Say It Ruined Them.
description: Machine-learning technologies are being used in film restoration for new home video releases. But some viewers strongly dislike the results.
content: In 1998, Geoff Burdick, an executive at James Cameron’s Lightstorm Entertainment, was hunched in front of a 12-inch monitor at a postproduction house, carefully preparing “Titanic” for release on LaserDisc and VHS. A state-of-the-art computer process had made it possible for Burdick and his team to scour the film frame by frame, removing tiny imperfections embedded in the original negative: little scratches, flakes of dirt, even water stains that smeared the image. The computer could erase these blemishes using a kind of copy-paste tool, concealing the defects with information from another frame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 307
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Biden’s Student Loan Repayment Plan Is Being Challenged. Here’s What to Know.
description: The income-driven plan known as SAVE has reduced payments for millions of borrowers. Lawsuits by Republican-led states are seeking to upend it.
content: When President Biden announced his plan to provide student debt relief for 43 million borrowers nearly two years ago, there was a piece to his program that attracted less attention: a new student loan repayment program that would cut monthly payments in half for millions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Nate Schweber
title: Hudson Yards ‘Vessel’ Sculpture Will Reopen With Netting After Suicides
description: The 150-foot-high tourist attraction, which closed in 2021, will be fitted with mesh to stop people from jumping.
content: Nearly three years after a series of suicides shut down the Vessel, the 150-foot-tall centerpiece of the Hudson Yards complex in Manhattan, the project’s developer said on Friday that it would reopen this year with new safety measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: A Closer Look at a Slight Shift in the Polls
description: An average of recent surveys, including the Times/Siena poll, finds President Biden inching closer to Donald Trump.
content: Is President Biden gaining in the polls? There have been signs of it ever since his State of the Union address last month, and a New York Times/Siena College poll released Saturday morning is the latest hint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Election Workers Face Flood of Threats, but Charges Are Few
description: The Justice Department has a task force focused on the thousands of threats against state and local officials who oversee voting, but most are protected by the First Amendment.
content: One week after the 2020 presidential election, Tina Barton, who as the clerk of Rochester Hills, Mich., oversaw voting there, sat down at her desk, coffee in hand, and listened to her voice mail messages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: But I’m All Grown Up With a Job of My Own
description: Caring colleagues might mean well, but your taking on new and more projects is none of their concern.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai, Yan Zhuang and John Yoon
title: Stabbing Attack in Sydney Kills at Least Six People
description: Shoppers hid in backrooms or ran screaming from the scene, while others stayed with injured victims. The police said they believed the attack was not a “terrorism incident.”
content: A man killed six people and injured at least 12 others during a stabbing rampage at a popular shopping mall in Sydney, Australia, on Saturday afternoon, in one of the country’s deadliest acts of mass violence in recent decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alvin L. Bragg Jr
title: What Martin Luther King Jr. Knew About Crime and Mental Illness
description: Mental illness isn’t a crime, and jail isn’t the answer for those experiencing it.
content: In September 1958, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was stabbed with a seven-inch steel letter opener. He had been autographing copies of his first book in Blumstein’s department store in Harlem. The woman who stabbed him was named Izola Ware Curry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cross-Tabs: April 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters Nationwide
description: Donald Trump leads Joe Biden, 46 percent to 45 percent, among registered voters.
content: Donald Trump leads Joe Biden, 46 percent to 45 percent, among registered voters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wyoming Democratic Caucus Results
description: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Wyoming Democratic presidential caucus.
content: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Wyoming Democratic presidential caucus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Toplines: April 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters Nationwide
description: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,059 registered voters from April 7 to 11, 2024.
content: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,059 registered voters from April 7 to 11, 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cross-Tabs: April 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate
description: Donald Trump leads Joe Biden, 47 percent to 46 percent, among the likely electorate.
content: Donald Trump leads Joe Biden, 47 percent to 46 percent, among the likely electorate.
source.name: The New York Times
